docs.snippet: The ruble hit a record low against the dollar and a main Russian share index was just above the level it reached after the 2008 global economic crisis....
docs.lead_paragraph: The ruble hit a record low against the dollar and a main Russian share index was just above the level it reached after the 2008 global economic crisis.
docs.abstract: Russia's economy is staggering from turbulent world stock markets and plummeting oil prices; ruble touches record low against dollar.

headline.main: Russian Economy Stumbles as Stocks and Oil Prices Fall
headline.print_headline: Russian Economy Reels as Stocks and Oil Fall

docs.snippet: The finding represented by far the most damning official link between the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, an ex-K.G.B. officer, and the highest levels of the Kremlin....
docs.lead_paragraph: The finding represented by far the most damning official link between the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, an ex-K.G.B. officer, and the highest levels of the Kremlin.
docs.abstract: Report by retired British judge Sir Robert Owen asserts Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin 'probably approved' 2006 operation to kill former KGB officer and Kremlin adversary Alexander V Litvinenko in London using poison polonium.

headline.main: Putin ‘Probably Approved’ Litvinenko Poisoning, British Inquiry Says
headline.print_headline: Putin Role Likely in Ex-Spy’s Death, Report Says

byline.contributor: Ivan Nechepurenko contributed reporting from Moscow.

docs.snippet: Britain’s inquiry into the death of Alexander Litvinenko further strains international relations with Russia....
docs.lead_paragraph: Britain’s inquiry into the death of Alexander Litvinenko further strains international relations with Russia.
docs.abstract: Editorial expresses shock following revelation that Russian Pres Vladimir Putin likely approved 2006 poisoning of former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko in London with toxic isotope polonium 210; holds one of biggest questions raised by disclosure is what effect it will have on international relations, particularly those between Great Britain and Russia.

headline.main: Mr. Putin and the Poisonous London Tea Party
headline.print_headline: Mr. Putin and the Fatal London Tea Party

docs.snippet: A look at the hurdles and the possibilities related to the negotiations diplomats hope to begin on Monday....
docs.lead_paragraph: A look at the hurdles and the possibilities related to the negotiations diplomats hope to begin on Monday.
docs.abstract: Q&A analyzes events and issues leading to delay of Geneva peace talks aimed at resolving Syrian conflict; Sec of State John Kerry and Russia's foreign minister, Sergey V Lavrov, met in Zurich to begin discussions but their meeting broke up inconclusively.

headline.main: Assessing the Road to the Syrian Peace Talks
headline.print_headline: Assessing the Difficult Road to the Syrian Peace Talks

byline.contributor: Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, Lebanon.

docs.snippet: The two countries are digging in for a battle that will continue regardless of any peace deal: the fight against the Islamic State extremist group....
docs.lead_paragraph: The two countries are digging in for a battle that will continue regardless of any peace deal: the fight against the Islamic State extremist group.
docs.abstract: Russian military increases its presence in Syria, establishing new airfield and opening dialogue with Sunni forces fighting Islamic State; competition with United States for allies on ground comes as diplomatic efforts to achieve cease-fire flounder; two powers' clashing strategies are becoming major obstacle to resolving conflict.

headline.main: Russia and U.S., While Pushing for Peace Talks, Jockey for Position in Syria
headline.print_headline: Russia and U.S., While Pushing Peace Talks, Compete for Allies in Syria

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, Helene Cooper from Brussels, and Michael S. Schmidt from Paris.
byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

docs.snippet: Poland is putting its own spin on a nuanced NATO plan to deter Moscow in eastern Europe without stationing permanent troops on Russia's borders, prompting disquiet from allies including Britain, which needs Warsaw's help in EU reform negotiations....
docs.lead_paragraph: Poland is putting its own spin on a nuanced NATO plan to deter Moscow in eastern Europe without stationing permanent troops on Russia's borders, prompting disquiet from allies including Britain, which needs Warsaw's help in EU reform negotiations.

headline.main: Poland Clouds NATO's Nuanced Russia Plan
headline.print_headline: Poland Clouds NATO's Nuanced Russia Plan

headline.print_headline: Russia Says Syria Talks Could Begin Jan. 27-28-Interfax

docs.snippet: Pictures of Syrian President Bashar Assad hang on nearly every building in the town of Salma, which government troops captured last week in one of their most significant advances since Russia intervened militarily on their side....

docs.snippet: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday he believed that, with effort and good faith on both sides, it would be possible to implement the Minsk agreements on Ukraine in coming months to allow for a lifting of sanctions on Russia....
docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday he believed that, with effort and good faith on both sides, it would be possible to implement the Minsk agreements on Ukraine in coming months to allow for a lifting of sanctions on Russia.

headline.main: Kerry Says Effort and Good Faith Could Lead to Lifting of Sanctions on Russia
headline.print_headline: Kerry Says Effort and Good Faith Could Lead to Lifting of Sanctions on Russia
